channel.title: My Password on RSCEmulation
channel.description:
This is the hash used for my password on RSCEmulation's live server:
980005896110be155019bf734d169e9eff9acefff9b0365231964d2114d86c75259d0ccb8fa3bec52a2b26308faec9b0d3dd96e5a2cf566f85ee42c283c13954
My unique salt is: uTW5/FJD<I`SFuoBe4b1RMWcPFSewM
I'm genuinely intrigued if anyone can do anything with it...
Login via: http://www.rscemulation.net/login.html

item.title: My Password on RSCEmulation
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Kryptix, post:9, topic:416685”]So are you saying that their salt should be sent to the client and then you encrypt their password using the supplied salt using JS, then sending the hash back instead of sending the password in plain-text and encrypting on the server?

Surely it’s a bad idea to let everyone know what their salt is when trying to login?[/quote]

I can’t think of why it would be a bad idea really, what use is their salt to them? It’s just to stop people from using rainbow tables, and if the database was compromised, the salt would be as well.

But if you were concerned, do what I said before, use the username as a salt and then hash it again on the server, anything is more secure than just sending the password over plaintext like you do now.

Read full topic

item.title: My Password on RSCEmulation
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Kryptix, post:8, topic:416685”]What I’m saying MITB…

You said to use sha1() to encrypt the $_POST data prior to sending with JS and then add the salt and encrypt it with SHA-512. That means that the sent data can be put through a rainbow table, right?[/quote]

You could use sha1, but you would also want to use a salt in the browser as well. But since you are already using sha512, and there is in fact a javascript implementation of that, there is no reason you shouldn’t just use it.

Read full topic

item.title: My Password on RSCEmulation
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:28, topic:416547”][quote]Also, rainbow tables are pretty complete these days, it’s not like they’re just taking random hashes anymore; a lot of them are actually taking the bruteforce approach and throwing all the hashes into the tables.
[/quote]Rofl no?[/quote]You’re completely right, because there are absolutely no projects that are specifically for generating rainbow tables…

Also, none of the non-existent projects are even remotely close to completing pretty important tables, I mean, it’s not like they’re just a few days away…
[hr][quote=“Kryptix, post:8, topic:416685”]What I’m saying MITB…

You said to use sha1() to encrypt the $_POST data prior to sending with JS and then add the salt and encrypt it with SHA-512. That means that the sent data can be put through a rainbow table, right?[/quote]You can always do sha512(sha1(salt + pass)). Of course the client would need to know the salt that was used when generating the hash in the database.

Read full topic

item.title: My Password on RSCEmulation
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:18, topic:416547”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=518446.msg3770870#msg3770870 date=1317675025]
Rainbow tables are useless when you use a salt.
[/quote]It depends. If, for instance, your salt was just a single, common character then rainbow tables would obviously still be useful.[/quote]

Maybe I should have said “unique per-hash salt” then? Which completely nullifies any use rainbow tables have.

Read full topic

item.title: My Password on RSCEmulation
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

Also, rainbow tables are pretty complete these days, it's not like they're just taking random hashes anymore; a lot of them are actually taking the bruteforce approach and throwing all the hashes into the tables.
Rofl no?

Read full topic

item.title: My Password on RSCEmulation
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“imthenull, post:26, topic:416547”]single character salts are actually useful, there’s a slim chance that rainbow tables wont have that specific word in it, with the salt, so pretty much anything is better than nothing, obviously.[/quote]You’re adding one character… I’d say an average password length is 7, so you’re making the password length 8. Bruteforcing that on a home computer can get all possible combinations done for 8 characters (alphanumeric w/ mixed case) in 17 hours @ 2.8 billion hashes per second. There are more powerful home machines that can do 33.1 billion hashes per second, that would take less than 2 hours to do it.

Also, rainbow tables are pretty complete these days, it’s not like they’re just taking random hashes anymore; a lot of them are actually taking the bruteforce approach and throwing all the hashes into the tables.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull
item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

single character salts are actually useful, there’s a slim chance that rainbow tables wont have that specific word in it, with the salt, so pretty much anything is better than nothing, obviously.

@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:21, topic:416547”][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=518446.msg3771636#msg3771636 date=1317741968]

[quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=518446.msg3771057#msg3771057 date=1317683643]

[/quote]That isn’t a salt…

Also, it should be at least 6 characters…
[/quote]Why do you say that?[/quote]It’s not a salt because it needs to be random.

It should be at least 6 characters because anything under that is useless. Even 6 is borderline.

item.title: My Password on RSCEmulation
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

There is no downside, but if they have javascript disabled, it will be transmitted to your server in plain-text anyway (you can’t do anything about that, except HTTPS), so you have to be able to handle that if it happens. (you can check if it’s a hash or not with the length)

A quick google shows me this:
http://jssha.sourceforge.net/

But of course you don’t have to just do a single hash, you could sha-1 the password with the username as a salt in the browser, then perform your sha-512 on it once it reaches the server, for a complete hash that looks something like this:

hash = sha512(512salt+sha1(username+password));

Either way is good.

Also, think about HTTPS, I pay $10-$15 per year per domain for cheap but well supported SSL certificates, and it’s very easy to set up server-side.

Read full topic

item.title: My Password on RSCEmulation
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

A strong hashing method is only part of the solution, I see you don’t even offer HTTPS, so you are still sending the password in plain-text over un-secure networks, and receiving it in plain-text on your server. You should hash the password with javascript in the browser before you send it across the network:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:10, topic:416539”]Look at SMF (like this forum) for instance, when you type in your username/password and click ‘submit’, if the user has javascript enabled (most do), it hashes the password and sends only the hash, not the password, over the network connection:

moparisthebest.com

moparisthebest.com

programming, irc, cars

Search for sha1.js in the html source code of the login page for more implementation details.[/quote]

I know you don’t use sha1, but you can use the basic method and substitute your hashing algorithm.

The other flaw in your system is solely solvable by secure-cookies and HTTPS, session hi-jacking, take a look at this browser plugin for how easy it is:
http://codebutler.com/firesheep

Read full topic
